title: Historical and longitudinal small area analysis of the effects of market-oriented reform on equity of access to NHS care
abstractText:
This project aims to explore the effects of two major market-oriented reforms introduced in the English National Health Service in the 1990s (general practitioner fund-holding and ‘internal market’ hospital competition) on socio-economic inequalities in some NHS specialist services, by introducing a large dataset covering the decade from 1991 to 2001 and developing the methodology to analyse it.

A new longitudinal small area dataset is assembled, following the same 8,500 English small areas (frozen 1991 electoral wards) for eleven years from 1991/2 to 2001/2. The research focuses on two common effective procedures - elective total hip replacements and revascularisations - which are often cited as examples of socio-economic inequality in health care.  The project constructs indices of hospital competition and GP fundholding, and also allows for geographical variations in population size, age, sex, need, supply, waiting time and other factors that influence use of care.
